title: U.S. Space Force seeks to work closer with allies in face of shared threats
summary: The procurement arm of the U.S. Space Force is making a major push to work more closely with allies abroad and is pressing the Pentagon to adjust classification policies to allow for more open sharing of information with trusted international partners.

title: UK funds surveillance satellite replacement lost in Virgin Orbit failure
summary: The U.K. is funding nearly half the cost of replacing the government-backed cubesat that British maritime surveillance venture Horizon Technologies lost in January in Virgin Orbit’s final launch attempt before bankruptcy.

title: ESA Pushes Ahead with Ariane 6 Testing
summary:
ESA announced 19 October that it had adapted the Ariane 6 testing schedule to enable teams to continue to tick off key milestones while work on a Thrust Vector Control (TVC) anomaly continues. The first hot fire test of an Ariane 6 core stage was completed on 18 July. Following that test, as teams worked […]
The post ESA Pushes Ahead with Ariane 6 Testing appeared first on European Spaceflight.

title: China rolls out rocket for Shenzhou-17 mission to Tiangong
summary: A crew of three astronauts is set to launch to China’s Tiangong space station next week for a six-month-long mission.

title: Skylo’s network to spread in 2024
summary: In recent months, Skylo has established partnerships with chipset manufacturers, satellite fleet operators and telecommunications providers.

title: Investing in Space: On satellites, the invisible backbone of global industry
summary: “Space-based technologies are the building blocks of innovation on Earth. GPS, geospatial intelligence and satellite communications are the invisible backbone that powers the world’s largest industries today.”

title: In annual report to Congress, Pentagon highlights China’s ‘refusal to engage’
summary: China’s continued pursuits of space technologies as a way to gain military superiority are once again highlighted in the Pentagon’s latest annual report on “Military and Security Developments Involving the People’s Republic of China.”

title: Artemis and Taming the Extraordinary
summary: Strategists and planners at NASA are mulling over questions of tempo for future human expeditions to the moon. Should Artemis involve a yearly campaign of smaller missions or consolidate expeditions, launching more ambitious (and, therefore, sporadic) efforts less often?

title: Cognitive Space wins two SDA contracts
summary: Cognitive Space said securing two SDA phase 2 awards in a matter of weeks underscores the value of the company’s Cognitive Inference Tasking (CNTIENT) software platform.

title: Launch industry asks Congress for regulatory reforms
summary: Industry officials used a Senate hearing to request reforms to the Federal Aviation Administration’s launch licensing process, warning of dire commercial and geopolitical implications if changes aren’t made.
